div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: THE EUROPEAN OUTLOOK
div.p: The impending collapse of the Algeciras Conference naturally suggests a survey of the present political conditions of Europe, for any eventuality may suddenly arise. The situation of Europe is analogous to that which existed in the time of Elizabeth, of William III., and of Pitt, when there was a danger that one Baropean Power might become so strong and so ambitions as to be a menace to the inde. pendence of the others, and when the preeminent Power on the Continent found that the path to supremacy lay through the conquest of Great Britain. Such a condition compels the co-operation of all States that value their independence, and in face of such a situation Great Britain has three times at least been forced, much against her will, to enter into European war as a member of a coalition. The Power which to day is tempted to follow the example of Spain under Philip II and of France under Louis XIV. and under Napoleon is, of course, Germany. The German Empire has an area, a population, an organisation, and an ecergy which give it a very high rank among the Powers of the world. But upon one point the German publicists hold an opinion with which we do not agree. They consider that a State which has great power will always abase that Power They say that England having great maritime power is sure to make a wrong use of it. We resent the suggestion, and no instance has been givan by them in which E gland has abused the oppor unities created for her by the possession of a strong Navy. Their principle, if it ware sound, would imply that Germany. being today exceedingly strong, was sure to abase her power by attacking some neighbour believed by her people to be unequal to a conflict with her. We cannot think as ill of Germany as these German political and strategioal writers profess to do. We do not expect Germans, because she has a large and well-organised Army, to attack France. We do not expect her, bacause she has a most excellent and rapidly. growing Navy, and because her Naval, General Staff has taken the exact measure of the British Admiralty and its antiquated organisation, to get up a quarrel with England and arrange an i invasion. Her wiser thinkera kaow that such gratuitous and wanton attacks are crimes which bring their own punishment. They know the result of the unscrupulous ambition of Louis XIV. They know that Napoleon so long as he was upsetting the abures of effete despotisms was successful, and that o soon as he began to misuse his power to interfere with the independent existence of national States was on the high road to rain. They know what Spain has had to suffer in onsequence of the Imperial aspirations of Philip II., what rain the great design of Louis XIV. brought upon France, and what misfortanes followed the refaeal of Napoleon to moderate his ambition They are well aware that the possible opportunity of a number of German victories in a war of aggression would not compensate for the blow which such a war would be to the cause even of German civilisation, which rests not upon German science or German art bat upon the honesty of the German character. It is because we rely upon that character and believe that it can and will hold the balance against the conning of strategists and the zeal of Chauvinists that we look for a peaceful future.

But it would be absurd not to see that the "German Emperor" is the subject of temptations Russia is for the present neutralised or paralysed. The German Army, prepared for a war against Russia and Frai ce, might have a great opportunity in a war against France alone. Great Britain could give little help even if disposed and determined to do so. Her Navy could not get at the German Navy, which can retire into the Baltio or into its impregnable Port Arthurs, of which there are several. Her Army, which has been mismanag. d for several years in a fashion, that delights her enemies, though it is better trained and more efficient in detail than ever, is yet too small and too little capable of expansion to be able to turn the balance in a Continental war. It could hardly resist invasion in case of naval mishap. Accordingly there is a plausible case for the tempters of the "German Emperor," and last year they had nearly won him. By the sacrifice of Delcassé France gave him time to think. He bas had leisure to reflect whether he will walk in the path of Louis XIV. and Napoleon or will remain true to the sound doctrine that Germany will be great by minding her own business, seeking no quarrels and imagining none where none are meant. The choice when it is deliberate can hardly be doubtful. Accordngly the people of England will do well to be ready to accept the goodwill of Germany 80 soon as there is evidence of it. Of course, in such matters evidence consists in acts, not in diplomatic speeches, nor in attempts to manage the Boglish Press, of which there have been too many. The people of Germany have always got on very well with the people of Bagland until their political leaders began to sow suspicion, Those leaders have resped what they have sown and had a fall harvest. They have helped to make the Entente Cordiale. Bot the moment they have decided to cht ge their tack there will be no difficulty about making their new intention clear.

Meanwhile for the British nation the situa tion is ambiguous. Is the German Emperor the disciple of Louis XIV. or is he resolved not to provoke needless wars, and to use his power for the good of mankind and of Barope ? Is he the touchy student looking out for a challenge or the quiet man who will not be provoked except by a great wrong, such as in fact no one is ikely to inflict upon him? We trust that the Emperor is a just and peaceful ruler, and not an imaginative or adventurous statesman. But in most men's minds either interpretation is possible. No one can assert with fall certainty that Germany may not in the near fatare disturb the peace of Europe. If we could rely on the German character such as it was in the last generation we should say that no doubt was possible. But no Englishman who has travelled in Germany in recent years, and who speaks the language and knows the people, thinks the national character what it was. A people once noted for historical knowledge now believes incredible myths about other countries. A temper once plac d is now irritable. The friends of peace and of civilisation continue to hope; but not without misgiving. In the e conditions our countrymen would do well to look to their defences and to the organisation of the country's forces of possible conflict. What we wish to point out to those who are watching the progress of events is that there is no reason wby Germany thould follow the nnhappy precedents to which reference has been made, and that, so long as she avoids them, there is no reason why her relations with England should not be as close atd as clear as st any previons period. It is a question which Germany, not England, bas to de ide. England w.ll Le true to her traditions.

div.head: Modern Cairene Architecture.
div.p: Mr. Divay, in an ar iule in the "Daily Telegrapb," remarka : Tbe Arabs of to day have lost the architectural ability with which they were formerly credited. The whole city of Cairo je now te ng rebuilt, not in accordance with tbe models of architeotorg instituted onder Arab, and even Turkish, role, bat in accordance with a sort of tastard medley, which I should describe as based apon the model of South Kensington and St. John's wood.

div.head: Fire at Alexandria.
div.p: This morning at about 10 o'olock a fire broke ont in the second floor of a house in Au&stasistreet, very close to the enormous shoonahs (dattiers) of the Société de Pressage et des Dépôts. The Pressage Company's storekeeper at once gave the alarm to the Alexandria Fire Brigade and we are pleased to hear from the manager of the company, Mr. Charray, that the promptitode with which the call was reponded to was quite phenomenal in its onlerity.! Within four or five minutes of the alarm having been given the firemen were at the scene of the outbreak and succeeded in localising the fire, thus preventing what m ght eavily have become a most serious confligration.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY
div.p: A far more porious situation appears to have arison between Egypt and Tarkøy over the frontier dispote than was allowed to trad-1 spiro in the onmmunications vooohsafed to the local Press. According to the statemente in the London Press the Ottoman foroes sotaally went so far as to adopt a menacing attirudo towards the officers of the Noor al Babr. Renter's Agency is responsible for this statement, and the tenonr of the following commanioation, which appeared in the Londoo nowspapers this day week. indispatably proves that a state of severe tension is existing. "Thol paragraph runs as follows:

"Renter's Agency learns that the situation | braght about by the persistence of the Tur: ki h troops in remaining in occapation of Tahab, on the Tarko Beyptian frontier of the Sinai Penipayla, has agaimed a serious aspoob, The Sultan's forces have not only heen e-tablishing posts in territory admittedly Reyption, but have also been tbreatening the officers of the Bgyptian ganboat lying in a neighbouring bay in the Gulf of Akaba.
"All local efforts to remedy this state of thinga bave prved ineffootive, the Tarka refa-ing to withdraw

"The British Government has now made diplomatio reprogontations at Constantinople, and a British offi var attached to the Bryptian army har been despatobed from Cairo to the Boone of action, to which bia. Majesty's orainer Diana h is at the same time been ordered to repair."
It will be interesting to learn if the statement made by Rentor's agency as to the threatening attitnde of the Tarks towards the officers of the Noar el Babr will be officially contradicted.

According to a statement emanating from Constantinople the position as to the frontier is this : In 1892 a firman was issned for the proxert Kbedive ; no mention was made in this firman of the Sinai Peninsnla, on the north eastern part of which Akaba ja witoated, bot afterwarda a letter from the Gand V ziar stafhd that Sidai should rem sin ander Khadivial administration on condition that Bgypt with drew her troops from Akıbe, Blwaatji. Mnol. lah, and Daba, all on the Otravad, rond to the Hedjas (Moona), whore Kgypt, with the cnn. sent of the Sultan, had maintained tronps to proteot pilgrims from Bedouins. The Egyptian troops were eventually withdrawn from the points mentioned.
A correspondent writes :

It would be interesting to know whether the Ottoman troops, engaged in the frontier dispute, are efficered by Gormina. In a para-1graph published in to-day's issue of the "Gasetta in the remarkably oatspokon statements on the gabject of Germany and Beypt in a recent work by a well-known German offiser, Major von Brachhaagan by namą, the plane of the anthor in regard to a hypothetical campaign. 80 far at least ng Bgypt and the Saez Canal were concerne l, rested on Garmany's obtaining a valuable ally in Tack-y. German and Tarkish troops might, for instance, Major von Brachhansen thinkı, overran Bzypt and reiza the Buez Canal, thereby interrupting Bngland's sea communication with India. The more frot of Germany acting in 00-0; eration with tbe foremost Mohamedan Power would necorsarily exercise a great influence on the Moslem popalation of India, and serious compliostions for Great Britain would certainly opene."

Of course these , anticipations deal with the contingency of a war being declared between England and Germany, but they are very significant for they are made by an officer in the Kaiser's army, and the book, where this scheme is advoosted, is finding a large circulation in Germany. The present frontier disputa shows how easily matters might be brought to a grave state of tension.

div.head: IMPORTANT LEGAL CASE
div.p: A case of great interest bas just been decided in Cairo. Mme. Carolina Tomich, who owns the two blocks of buildings situated in the Opera-square and the Sharis el Manakh- one of the most valuable sites in the Capital and which brings in a yearly rental of about £5.000,-entered last year into an agreement with Fahmy Effendi Ismail, formerly employed at the Contentieux of the Ministry of the Interior. By this contract, which was for fifteen years, it was agreed that the latter had to pay during this period at total of £3 300 per annum and, at the same time, to make all the necessary repairs. Fahmy Effendi in 1905 and his heirs brought an action seeking to enforce the contract of which Mme. Tomich had given notice of cancelment in consequence of the death of the lessee.

The case came on for hearing three weeks ago before the Première Chambre Civile of the Mixed Tribunals, presided by Mr. Pranières, President of that Court, Maitres Em. Manusardi and Rod appeared over for the defendant, whilst the plaintiffs were represented by Maitre Alphonse Colucci. Judgment was given on Monday upholding the contention of the former that the contract entered into between the parties ceased by the death of Fahmy Effendi Ismail, who was declared to have been a "mandataire salarié" and not a "locataire" notwithstanding the fact that the agreement distinctly stated that he was a locataire.
The judgment is considered of great importance in view of the fact that all similar contracts now in existence could not be enforced before the local courts of law.

BULLETIN HEBDOMADAIRE
div.p: Alexandrie, VENDREDI à Midi le 23 Fevrier 1906

row.cell: Pour les Feves, Orges, Bles, Lentilles, Mais et Oignons, la consommation locale n'est connue respectivement que les 31 Mars et 30 Novembre
N.B.– L'année pour les Blés et les Lentilles commence au 1er Avril, pour les Mais le 1er Décembre, pour les Oignons le 1er Mars.
COTON SUIVANT LES TYPES DE L'ASSOCIATION
Marché des Cotons: haussant pour les afifis et sans changement pour les autres qualités.
